p: With the exception of the B. obovata preparation, the decoctions were also potent inhibitors of HeLa cell proliferation ( Figure 6(b)) and were generally more potent inhibitors against this cell line than against Caco2. As for Caco2 proliferation, the T. carpentariae decoction was the most potent inhibitor of HeLa cell proliferation ( Figure 6(b), Table 2). Indeed, the T. carpentariae decoction blocked 100% of the HeLa proliferation during the screening experiment, and an IC 50 of 85 μg/mL was calculated when the decoction was tested across a range of concentrations. The C. equisetifolia, E. tetrodonta, and V. vexillata decoctions were also strong inhibitors of HeLa cell growth, inhibiting proliferation by 60–90% ( Figure 6(b)). Furthermore, IC 50 values against HeLa of 450, 588, and 126 μg/mL were calculated for these decoctions, respectively.
